content:
The "Supporting Transparent Regulatory and Environmental Actions in Mining Act" or the "STREAM Act" requires the publication of scientific products for rules, environmental impact statements, assessments, and economic assessments under Title V of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977. The STREAM Act mandates the Secretary to make all scientific products used in developing rules and assessments publicly available 90 days before publication. This includes raw data for federally funded scientific products to ensure transparency and compliance. The STREAM Act requires the Secretary to release scientific products used in rule development 90 days before publication. If the products are not made available, the comment period for draft rules is extended, and the effective date of final rules is delayed. If products are withheld for over 6 months, the rule must be withdrawn unless there is a threat to human life. The STREAM Act mandates the release of scientific products for rule development 90 days before publication. Failure to do so results in extended comment periods and delayed rule implementation, unless there is a severe threat to human life. The STREAM Act requires the release of scientific products for rule development 90 days before publication. Raw data is defined as computational or qualitative data supporting scientific findings, excluding copyrighted, personally identifiable, or sensitive information. The STREAM Act mandates the release of scientific data for rule development, excluding sensitive information, and aligns with existing regulations under various healthcare acts. SEC. 3. STUDY OF THE EFFECTIVENESS OF CERTAIN RULE. Amendment to Title VII of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 for a study on the effectiveness of specific rules. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with the Interstate Mining Compact Commission and its State members, will conduct a study with the National Academy of Sciences to assess the effectiveness of the Surface Coal Mining and Reclamation Operations Permanent Regulatory Program in protecting streams through stream buffer zones. If inefficiencies are found, recommendations for improvement will be included in the study. The Board on Earth Sciences and Resources will report study results to relevant committees and agencies, with authorized funding of $1,000,000 for fiscal years 2016 and 2017. The Secretary is prohibited from issuing new regulations related to the Stream Protection Rule. The Secretary is prohibited from issuing new regulations related to the Stream Protection Rule until study results are submitted. Amendments are made to the table of contents in the first section of the Act. SEC. 4. COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER FEDERAL LAWS.

Amends Section 702 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 to ensure compliance with other federal laws. Prohibits the Secretary from duplicating actions taken under other Acts or regulations. The attestation is signed by Karen L. Haas, the Clerk.
